verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron,
verses.comment: This continues the pattern of God speaking directly to Moses and Aaron, emphasizing divine authority and apostolic leadership (see Lev. 1:1).

verses.text: "This is the statute of the law that the LORD has commanded: Tell the Israelites to bring you a red heifer without defect, in which there is no blemish, and on which no yoke has ever been placed."
verses.comment: The red heifer symbolized purity, to be used in a unique sacrifice. The requirement for no blemish prefigures Christ as the spotless sacrifice (see Heb. 9:13-14).

verses.text: You shall give it to Eleazar the priest, and it shall be taken outside the camp and slaughtered before him.
verses.comment: The animal is killed outside the camp, matching the later typology of Jesus’ crucifixion outside Jerusalem (Heb. 13:11-12). Priestly mediation is key.

verses.text: Eleazar the priest shall take some of its blood with his finger and sprinkle it seven times toward the front of the Tent of Meeting.
verses.comment: Sevenfold sprinkling signifies perfection and completeness in ritual purity, reflecting God's perfect sanctification.

verses.text: The heifer shall be burned in his sight. Its hide, flesh, blood, and dung shall be burned.
verses.comment: Total consumption underscores the complete offering, pointing toward an all-encompassing sacrifice for purification.

verses.text: The priest shall take cedar wood, hyssop, and scarlet yarn and throw them into the fire burning the heifer.
verses.comment: Cedar, hyssop, and scarlet are symbols used in other purification rites and tied to Christ’s Passion (the hyssop at the cross, John 19:29).

verses.text: Then the priest shall wash his clothes and bathe his body in water, and afterward he may come into the camp; but the priest shall be unclean until evening.
verses.comment: Even priests require purification, foreshadowing Christian baptismal washing and ongoing daily cleansing.

verses.text: The one who burns the heifer must wash his clothes in water and bathe in water and will remain unclean until evening.
verses.comment: Contact with the sacrificial remains renders a person unclean, again stressing ritual purity as a preparation for communion with God.

verses.text: And a man who is clean shall gather up the ashes of the heifer and store them outside the camp in a clean place. These shall be kept by the Israelites for water for impurity: it is a purification offering.
verses.comment: The ashes are kept for ongoing purification—an early sign of sacramental means extending ritual grace, helpful for later doctrine on sanctifying means.

verses.text: The one who gathers the ashes of the heifer must wash his clothes and will remain unclean until evening. This shall be a permanent statute to the Israelites and to the foreigner who lives among them.
verses.comment: Purity laws apply equally to foreigners, pointing to God’s plan for universal inclusion into His covenant.

verses.text: "Whoever touches the dead body of any person will be unclean for seven days."
verses.comment: Death brings ritual impurity, signifying the separation sin causes—a theme fully addressed in Christ’s resurrection and deliverance.

verses.text: He must purify himself with the water on the third day and on the seventh day, and so be clean; but if he does not purify himself on the third and seventh day, he will not be clean.
verses.comment: The third and seventh days have resonance with resurrection (cf. Jesus on the third day, Matt. 27:63) and spiritual completion.

verses.text: Anyone who touches a dead body, the corpse of a man who has died, and does not purify himself, defiles the LORD’s tabernacle, and that person shall be cut off from Israel. Because the water for impurity was not sprinkled on him, he remains unclean; his uncleanness is still on him.
verses.comment: Remaining unclean blocks communion with God’s sanctuary; the sprinkling water foreshadows effective sacramental cleansing.

verses.text: "This is the law when a man dies in a tent: Anyone who comes into the tent and all who are in the tent shall be unclean for seven days."
verses.comment: Uncleanness is shared by all present, reflecting corporate responsibility and the need for ritual action together.

verses.text: Every open vessel that has no cover fastened on it will be unclean.
verses.comment: Objects too can receive impurity, leading to doctrines about sanctified material objects and careful stewardship.

verses.text: Whoever touches in the open field anyone killed by a sword, or a dead body, or a human bone, or a grave, shall be unclean for seven days.
verses.comment: Contact with death always requires purification, symbolizing God’s design to remove sin’s effects in every situation.

verses.text: For the unclean, they shall take some ashes from the burnt purification offering and put fresh water over them in a vessel.
verses.comment: Water mixed with ashes forms the ritual, blending physical signs with spiritual effects—the consistent shape of sacraments.

verses.text: A clean person shall take hyssop, dip it in the water, and sprinkle it over the tent, all the vessels, and the people present, including anyone who touched a bone, a slain person, a corpse, or a grave.
verses.comment: Hyssop’s use echoes the Passover, and later, Christ’s sacrifice sprinkled for believers—pointing to spiritual purification by Christ.

verses.text: The clean person shall sprinkle the unclean on the third and seventh days. After he has purified them on the seventh day, they must wash their clothes, bathe in water, and at evening they shall be clean.
verses.comment: Purification follows God’s precise timing, both in ritual and ultimately in Christ’s resurrection work after three days.

verses.text: But the man who is unclean and does not purify himself, that person shall be cut off from the congregation, because he has defiled the sanctuary of the LORD. The water for impurity has not been sprinkled on him; he remains unclean.
verses.comment: Refusal to accept purification excludes from the people of God—revealing both exclusion and the necessity of mediator-administered means of grace.

verses.text: This shall be a permanent statute for them. The one who sprinkles the water for impurity shall wash his clothes, and anyone who touches the water for impurity will be unclean until evening.
verses.comment: Administering ritual purification also requires purity—a structure resembling later administration of sacraments, with ordered procedure.

verses.text: Whatever the unclean person touches will be unclean, and anyone who touches it will be unclean until evening.
verses.comment: The transmission of uncleanness reveals the pervasive effect of sin and death—a logic reversed in Christ, whose holiness spreads to the faithful.
